thread.title: House Panel Casts Pre-Dawn Vote To Keep Obamacare Overhaul Moving Forward
thread.title_full: House Panel Casts Pre-Dawn Vote To Keep Obamacare Overhaul Moving Forward

author: Jack Davis
title: House Panel Casts Pre-Dawn Vote To Keep Obamacare Overhaul Moving Forward

organizations.name: trumpcare’  ways and means committee chair

text:
House Panel Casts Pre-Dawn Vote To Keep Obamacare Overhaul Moving Forward "I sincerely thank my colleagues ,,," by Jack Davis March 9, 2017 at 7:27am Share on Facebook 677 Tweet Email Email Print Advertisement - story continues below 
With Democrats voicing their objections, the Republican-controlled House Ways and Means Committee acted early Thursday to move forward the process of replacing Obamacare. 
The 23-16 vote came shortly after 4 a.m. The House Energy and Commerce Committee, which was also reviewing the bill, had not completed its review as of Thursday morning. 
Next stop for the legislation is the House Budget Committee. The current timetable calls for the proposal to go for a full House vote within a few weeks. Advertisement - story continues below Kellyanne Conway Defends GOP Healthcare Bill, But Hesitates To Call It ‘Trumpcare’ 
Ways and Means Committee Chair Rep. Kevin Brady, R-Texas, said the process was fast but also fully public. 
“Unlike Obamacare , where members of this Committee were presented a 794-page bill at midnight for voting mere hours later, the 57-page bill before us today was posted two days ago for all of America to read,” Brady said. 
In a statement released after the vote, he said that the committee’s actions shows Republicans are serious about keeping President Donald Trump’s pledge to replace Obamacare. Advertisement - story continues below 
“Ways and Means Republicans just passed legislation that will help Americans finally have access to affordable health care,” Brady said in a statement following the vote. 
“This legislation reflects President Trump’s strong commitment to improving health care for all Americans. I sincerely thank my colleagues for their hard work and commitment to delivering on the President’s promise,” he said. 
The bill, unveiled Monday, has been the target of widespread criticism from Democrats, conservative Republicans and healthcare groups such as the American Medial Association and the American Hospital Association. 
White House press secretary Sean Spicer suggested the White House was not planning to appease all critics. Advertisement - story continues below
